02/07/2007 - El Director General de Aduanas, Dr. Ricardo Echegaray orden? a primera hora de hoy, que se dictara un Alerta a todas las Aduanas que integran la red de intercambio de Informacion RILO , que administra la Organizacion Mundial de Aduanas (O.M.A), con el objeto de intensificar los contoles ante la eventualidad de que, el reloj que perteneciera al General Manuel Belgrano, y que fuera robado del Museo Hist?rico Nacional, hubiese sido producto de una operacion orquestada por alguna organizacion dedicada al trafico ilicito de bienes culturales.

"El robo ocurri? el s?bado, pero reci?n tomamos conocimiento hoy - dijo Echegaray - por lo que si se trata de un coleccionista dedicado al contrabando del patrimonio cultural, la experiencia nos ha ense?ado que la salida al exterior ya se pudo haber consumado. Tambi?n estamos lanzando dos alertas m?s; una destinada a todas las Aduanas del pa?s para que intensifiquen los controles en la salida de pasos fronterizos, puertos y aeropuertos autorizados para el tr?fico internacional de mercader?as. El Alerta comprende tanto el movimiento de cargas, y pasajeros, encomendando adoptar medidas que minimicen la la alteraci?n del flujo de tr?nsito, agreg?.

"A medida que podamos reunir informaci?n y antecedentes del robo - se?al? Echegaray - podremos construir perfiles de riesgo que perfeccionen los controles y eviten el impacto en el flujo del comercio exterior. Lanzamos otra alerta a las fuerzas de seguridad, Gendarmeria, Prefectura y Policia Aeroportuaria para que tomen los recaudos que estimen necesario en orden a la competencia que tienen a su cargo en los extensos ambitos fronterizos que no estan autorizados para el trafico internacional de mercaderias.

La Policia Federal tambi?n est? trabajando, porque precisamente el museo hizo la denuncia en sede policial. Durante la ma?ana tomaremos contacto con el Director del museo para que nos facilite infografias, fotografias, y detalles especificos que permitan orientar el control en la Argentina y en el mundo. Durante la jornada habr? contactos de la Organizacion Mundial de Aduanas e INTERPOL en Europa.

Hay que tener en cuenta que estamos tras la b?squeda de un reloj muy valioso. Que el control en el mundo se realiza por an?lisis de riesgo, porque es imposible controlar el 100 por ciento de las cargas. Esto es as? desde la antiguedad. En casos de contrabando de bienes culturales las Aduanas hemos tenido resultados positivos mayoritariamente con la investigacion posterior. Los coleccionistas terminan ofreciendo en subastas costos?simas estos bienes. Ac? puede estar la clave para profundizar la b?squeda. En esta linea hemos trabajado en las ?ltimas investigaciones.

A titulo ejemplificativo concluimos recientemente un trabajo brillante con la Aduana norteamericana(ICE Inmigration - Customs - Enforcement) sobre contrabando de restos f?siles. Pr?ximamente ser?n restituidos a la Argentina. En este caso se trabajo con paciencia en la investigacion posterior.

Autoridades del Museo Hist?rico Nacional descubrieron el s?bado que hab?a sido robado de esas instalaciones el reloj que perteneci? al general Manuel Belgrano.

La pieza, detenida a las nueve y fabricada en oro, fue la que el pr?cer entreg? en su lecho de muerte a su m?dico, el escoc?s Jos? Redhead, como pago de honorarios ante la carencia de otros recursos econ?micos, por lo que constituye un s?mbolo de la abnegaci?n de Belgrano.

La ausencia de la reliquia fue notada por las autoridades del museo ?ubicado en Parque Lezama? en la noche del s?bado, despu?s de que la sala estuviera abierta, de 11 a 18, como todos los d?as salvo los lunes, seg?n dijeron en el establecimiento.

Se trata de un reloj de bolsillo con cadena que constitu?a toda la fortuna del creador de la bandera nacional al momento de su deceso como consecuencia de la hidropes?a, el 20 de junio de 1820, pocos d?as despu?s de cumplir 50 a?os.

La Asamblea del a?o XIII lo hab?a premiado con 40.000 pesos por sus important?simas victorias contra las fuerzas realistas, que este abogado y militar patriota don? para la construcci?n de escuelas p?blicas en Santiago del Estero, Tucum?n, Jujuy y la hoy boliviana Tarija.

Su pobreza al morir era tal que la l?pida de su tumba fue improvisada con el m?rmol de una c?moda de su hermano Miguel. En aquel entonces, el gobierno central le deb?a 18 meses de sueldo.

El director de la sala del museo, Jos? Antonio P?rez Goll?n, hizo la denuncia ante la comisar?a 14.

En el Museo Hist?rico Nacional, ubicado en Defensa al 1600, se conservan distintos objetos de valor cultural desde la ?poca de la colonia hasta principios del siglo XX.

Entre otras reliquias se cuentan el catalejo de Beresford y el sable de San Mart?n, el ?leo de Prilidiano Pueyrred?n que muestra a Manuelita Rosas, la cama de Sobremonte, el uniforme de G?emes, los ?leos de Candido L?pez sobre la Guerra del Paraguay y el chambergo de Bartolom? Analizan video grabado en el momento del robo del reloj de Belgrano

La Justicia cuenta con una filmaci?n del momento en que el valioso reloj que perteneci? al general Manuel Belgrano fue robado del Museo Hist?rico Nacional, seg?n revel? el director de esa instituci?n, Jos? Antonio P?rez Goll?n.

04/07/2007

La Justicia cuenta con una filmaci?n del momento en que el valioso reloj que perteneci? al general Manuel Belgrano fue robado del Museo Hist?rico Nacional, seg?n revel? el director de esa instituci?n, Jos? Antonio P?rez Goll?n.
 
El funcionario indic? en declaraciones radiales, que se cuenta con una grabaci?n de circuito cerrado, que fue entregada a los investigadores del caso, pese a que admiti? que las im?genes son de baja calidad. P?rez Goll?n confirm? que entreg? a la Justicia esa grabaci?n -hecha con las c?maras del circuito cerrado de televisi?n de la sala de donde fue sustra?do el reloj que perteneci? al general Belgrano-, que consta de im?genes "de baja resoluci?n".

Se?al?, al respecto, que esas im?genes que pueden observarse en la cinta "pasan muy r?pido", por lo que no se sabe si servir?n para esclarecer el robo. En lo que respecta al Museo, el funcionario dijo que ya han "agotado todo lo que se considera que se debe hacer" para tratar de recuperar la hist?rica pieza faltante. "Nos comunicamos con la Polic?a, con la Aduana y con Interpol. Hemos hecho todo lo que ten?amos que hacer", dijo el director del Museo donde se produjo el robo.

Esta ma?ana, Ra?l Alberto de la Mano, presidente del Centro Cultural Belgraniano, asegur? que el robo del reloj produjo en los integrantes de esa asociaci?n "un gran dolor". "Nos tiene realmente muy dolidos ya que este robo supera todo lo material. Ese reloj significa toda la grandeza de este pr?cer", dijo el presidente del centro, en declaraciones a Radio Rivadavia.

Seg?n estimaciones de expertos de la Aduana Argentina, el reloj de bolsillo que fue robado podr?a alcanzar un valor cercano a los 400 mil euros en el "mercado negro" de tr?fico de piezas hist?ricas. En esa l?nea, voceros de la Aduana Argentina y de Interpol -fuerza que est? trabajando en el caso-, advirtieron que recuperar esa pieza requerir? de una paciente y exhaustiva investigaci?n, que no ser? sencilla y que podr?a demorarse bastante tiempo.

Los investigadores consideran que el reloj fue robado por una organizaci?n que se dedica a este tipo de delitos con patrimonios culturales, y que sab?a de la "vulnerabilidad" del Museo Hist?rico Nacional, al punto que la vitrina en donde se expon?a el reloj -que tiene cadena y es de oro y esmalte- no fue violentada.

Reward offered in McHenry County copper thefts

WOODSTOCK, Ill. (AP) - A series of copper thefts since mid-May have prompted Crime Stoppers of McHenry County to offer a reward of 1 thousand dollars for information leading to an arrest.

Some of the copper stolen was cable from the Illinois Railway Museum in Union.

The museum reported the theft of more than five thousand dollars in copper cable, trolley wire and locomotive radiators in recent break-ins. In each case, the fence was cut.

Police blame the thefts on the high price of scrap copper. Other thefts have been reported in Harvard, Crystal Lake and Woodstock.

Gang escapes with ?75k haul from art theft
Jul 3 2007
By Mark Mudie


BALACLAVA-CLAD burglars stole more than ?75,000-worth of paintings from a Godstone mansion in a late-night raid.

Surrey Police has released pictures of the paintings, described as "distinctive", hoping that someone might have seen them and can help them trace the thieves.

Five men broke into a house in Leigh Place Lane, between 11pm on Wednesday, May 30 and 1am on Thursday, May 31 and snatched a number of paintings, all worth thousands of pounds.

Their haul included a pair of Thomas Hand paintings worth an estimated ?26,000, a George White and a George Knapton picture each worth about ?15,800, and a John Heins Senior worth ?14,000.

Most of the stolen goods were oil on canvas paintings, including Sir Godfrey Kneller's Portrait of Sarah, Duchess of Marlborough valued at ?4,800, John Heins Senior's Portrait of Lydia Harvey, George Knapton's Portrait of a Boy Archer and Thomas Hand's Gypsy family Outside a Barn and Peasants and a Pig.


The burglars also got away with a number of original paintings in the raid, including Shooting Party by George White.

Investigating officer Detective Constable Claire Langley said the paintings were "very distinctive" and would be recognisable to anyone who had seen them.

She said: "These are very distinctive items. They are easily recognisable so someone may remember seeing them for sale either in a shop, a car boot sale or perhaps on the Internet.

"Surrey Police will work to specifically target burglars and handlers of stolen goods.

"I am appealing to members of the art community to contact me,or Crimestoppers in confidence,if you have any information regarding the whereabouts of these valuable paintings."

Anyone with information should contact DC Langley at Caterham CID on 0845 125 2222, or alternatively call Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.

Workers destroy ancient Chinese tombs: media
Tue Jul 3, 2007 9:19AM EDT

BEIJING (Reuters) - About 10 ancient tombs dating back nearly 1,800 years have been destroyed by construction workers building an IKEA branch in Nanjing in southeastern China, a city newspaper said on Tuesday.

The tombs -- from the "six dynasties" period from AD 220 to 589 -- were uncovered on the outskirts of the ancient capital in Jiangsu province, the Nanjing Morning Post said.

City archaeologists told the newspaper the tombs might have been those of a wealthy family of the period as the workmanship was of high quality. The tombs were constructed of green bricks embroidered with ornate lotus patterns.

The tombs were destroyed by excavation machines and bulldozers making way for an outlet for the Swedish IKEA home furnishings chain, according to the report.

"The tops of some of the tombs were chopped off by bulldozers, disclosing some green bricks," it said, citing a witness.

"The situation of another tomb was even more miserable, because it was dug from the centre by an excavator, leaving only part of the coffin hanging on the mud wall," it said.

A spokesman for IKEA was not immediately available for comment.

Archaeologists from the Nanjing Museum have asked the developers to halt construction while they research the site and collect the artifacts, the report said, but it was not clear whether the work had been stopped.

Under Chinese law, people or work units found destroying "ancient tombs" can be fined 50,000 to 500,000 yuan (about $6,600-$65,700) but the laws are weakly enforced, the newspaper said.

Developers would sometimes rather pay the fine than delay or cancel construction projects, it added.

'Manuscript in London is not Gandhi's last writing'
3 Jul 2007

NEW DELHI: The rare manuscript of Mahatma Gandhi written 19 days before his assassination, which was held back from auction in London by Christie's, was not the last piece authored by him.

"This is not his last manuscript. In our collections, we have a similar handwritten draft, which is dated January 12, 1948. We also have another document of January 27, 1948," Nehru Memorial Museum and Library (NMML) Director Mirdula Mukherjee said on Tuesday.

She said it is for the Ahmedabad-based Navjivan Trust to decide whether NMML should keep the manuscript when the government gets it back from Britain.

"We have one of the largest collections of Gandhiji's memorabilia," she said. "It is for the Trust to decide whether we are the best institution to preserve the writings of Gandhiji. They have reposed their trust with us a number of times. And we are hopeful that this time too they will trust us," she said.

Describing the move to bring back the manuscript back to India as "a big victory for India and the Indian government", she said "now there was no danger of it going into private hands".

Christie's agreed to withdraw the Mahatma's manuscript from auction so that the Indian government can acquire it.

Christie's had earlier fixed a reserve price of 9,000 to 12,000 pounds for Gandhiji's manuscript written on January 11, nineteen days before his assassination, and which was published in his journal Harijan .

India's decision to make a bid for the manuscript started after reports from London said it was a letter and not a handwritten manuscript of the Father of the nation, Mukherjee said.

"When the picture became clear, we knew that we would be able to procure the manuscript as we did in 1996 when we served a legal notice to a British auction house for trying to sell a manuscript of Gandhiji's," Mukherjee said, adding that India was planning to serve a legal notice on the auction house to stop the sale.

Mukherjee said in 1996 London-based Phillips Sons and Neale stopped the auction after they were served a legal notice by the Indian High Commission that the manuscript was "stolen property" and the ownership lies with Navjiwan Trust.

The manuscripts reached the auction house after Gandhiji's typist, V Kalayanam passed it to a temple and gave them permission to sell it to raise money to build a temple in Hawai.

The Indian government filed a case in Chennai and in London to stop the auction. The Chennai court passed an injunction and ordered the auction house to stop the sale. "Following the order, a legal settlement was entered into between the auctioneer, Navjiwan Trust and other parties.

The manuscripts were then given to India," she said. Mukherjee said the Trust decided to hand over the manuscript to the museum as they had the means to preserve them.

"We are hoping that no money will be exchanged this time too to acquire the manuscript," she said. The handwritten article was published in "Harijan".

Musician's rare violin goes missing from NYC subway station
July 3, 2007, 10:47 PM EDT

NEW YORK (AP) _ A musician whose rare 20th-century violin went missing after he fell asleep in a hot subway station pleaded for the return of his instrument Tuesday night.

Tom Chiu, a Juilliard School graduate and founder of the avant-garde ensemble Flux Quartet, said his Scarampella violin and his backpack were stolen June 27 after a gig in Brooklyn.

He said it was raining that night and he went into the hot and humid subway station and fell asleep. When he awoke, he said, his bags were gone.

"It's been my heart and soul for the last 13 years," Chiu said of the violin. "There is also a precious bow that I have used since childhood and other items in my violin case. All have great sentimental value to me and are completely irreplaceable. I hope the person who has my violin will return it to me. I would be forever grateful."

Chiu would not say what the violin, which originally belonged to his parents, was worth.

The violin was made by Stefano Scarampella, one of the most highly regarded violin makers from the early 20th century in Italy.

DEUTSCH HEIRS CALL ON SWEDEN TO RETURN STOLEN NOLDE PAINTING
July 03, 2007

(New York, New York, July 3, 2007) The heirs of Otto Nathan Deutsch have called on Sweden to return the Nolde painting "Blumengarten (Utenwarf)". The painting is currently located at the Moderne Museet in Stockholm.

The original owner, Otto Nathan Deutsch was a prominent Jewish businessman living in Frankfurt, Germany during the Nazi period. After having lost his business due to Nazi persecution and after having to pay Jewish taxes and prohibitive exit taxes, he left Nazi Germany in 1938/1939 for Amsterdam. The Nolde painting was left behind with other paintings and household goods with a German moving company in Frankfurt and were to be delivered to Deutsch in Amsterdam, but the paintings and household items never arrived. After WWII, family members inquired as to the whereabouts of the paintings, but were told by the moving company that they were destroyed in bombing attacks. The Deutsch heirs filed claims with Germany for the loss of the paintings and household items after WWII and received a small compensation for their loss.   

After having acknowledged that the painting was looted/stolen from the Deutsch family, the Swedish government stated in a letter from their attorney that it purchased the painting from the Ketterer Galerie in Lugano, Switzerland in 1960's. It is believed that no provenance was given for the painting at the time of the sale.

It is not currently known how the Ketterer Galerie obtained the painting, including who consigned or sold it to them. Records regarding the sale are believed to be held at the Henze Ketterer Galerie in Wichtrachten/Bern, Switzerland.  

The Swedish Cultural Ministry issued a statement last week that it had given the assignment to the Moderne Museet to make a settlement with the Deutsch heirs without delay, taking into account the principles of the Washington Conference on Holocaust Looted Assets.

Greek police find hundreds of stolen relics
Reuters | Wednesday, 4 July 2007

Greek police have found more than a thousand pieces of artefacts dating back to ancient Greece after raiding a suspect's house near the southern city of Corinth, police said.

A 58 year-old man, who was also found with a dozen ancient and Byzantine period coins on his person, was arrested and will be charged with antiquities theft.

"The suspect is probably part of a wider group active in the Corinth area, as the artefacts seem to come from illegal digs in the region," police said.

"The confiscated artefacts are not very valuable as they are mostly small items, but all such activity is illegal."

Police confiscated more than 1300 items including small ancient clay idols, urns, pottery shards and bronze rings, dating from between the 6th and 4th century BC, police said.

A further raid on the suspect's house subsequently found excavation equipment and books detailing Mycenean and Classical antiques, police said.

There are thousands of archaeological sites scattered around Greece, and the government has pledged to crack down on the illegal excavation and smuggling of its national heritage.

Sculpture blackmailer fined $4000
NZPA | Wednesday, 4 July 2007

A man found guilty of receiving a $250,000 sculpture and blackmailing its owners was today sentenced to 300 hours' community work and ordered to pay reparations of $4000, in the High Court at Wellington.

Brenden John Marshall, 39, was in May found guilty of receiving the three metre-by-three metre sculpture, stolen from outside a restaurant in Waikanae, north of Wellington.

He was also found guilty of blackmailing the owners, threatening to cut up the artwork and sell it to a scrap metal dealer if they did not pay a ransom.

In sentencing, Justice Simon France said Marshall was nearly 40 years-old and had made a concerted effort to sort his life out, by quitting drugs and alcohol.

The bronze sculpture Long Horizon, moulded and cast by Palmerston North artist Paul Dibble, was stolen from outside the cafe Swell on the Kapiti Coast on October 6, 2005.

During the trial crown prosecutor Kenneth Stone said Marshall made a video of the sculpture, delivering it to the owners via the editor of the local Kapiti Observer newspaper, Diane Joyce.

One of the sculpture's owners, Maggie Mouat, watched the film and agreed to pay $6000 to get it back.

Later, Marshall called her to increase the ransom by $4000 and some days later an exchange meeting took place.
